div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, January 7, 1903
div1.p:
Believe Congress Should Recognize Serv-
ices of Col. Walter Reed.

A hearing was given yesterday by the
House Committee on Pensions on the bill
introduced by Mr. Hay, of Virginia, which
provides “That the Secretary of the In-
terior be, and he is hereby, authorized
and directed to place on the pension roll
the name of Emily Lawrence Reed, widow
of Walter Reed, late a colonel in the
United States army, Medical Corps, and
pay her a pension at the rate of $333.33 1-3
per month.”

Col. Reed is the officer who discovered
that yellow fever is transmitted through
the medium of mosquito bites, having
been in charge of the experiments which
were conducted in Cuba. The Senate
already has passed a bill pensioning Mrs.
Reed at the rate of $125 a month.

Among those who appeared before the
committee yesterday and urged the pas-
sage of the measure were President Gil-
man, of Johns Hopkins University; Prof,
Welch, of the same institution; Prof Al-
exander Graham Bell, Gen. Robert M.
O'Reilly. Surgeon General of the army
and Maj. J. R. Keen, who was in Cuba
with Col. Reed. They declared that Col.
Reed's discovery is one of the greatest
of the age, ranking with that of vaccin-
ation and antiseptic surgery. No action
was taken by the committee.
